hints.content: Start by understanding what a palindrome is. A palindrome reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 'abba' and 'cc' are palindromes.
Consider how you can form pairs of words. For a pair of words to contribute to a palindrome, one word should be the reverse of the other. For instance, 'lc' and 'cl' can form part of a palindrome.
Count how many pairs of words you can form. Use a dictionary to track the occurrences of each word and its reverse. This will help you identify how many complete pairs you can use.
Think about how to handle words that are palindromic themselves, like 'gg'. You can use one of these words in the middle of your palindrome if you have an even number of pairs.
When counting pairs, remember that each word can only be used once. If you have multiple occurrences of the same word, only consider the maximum pairs you can form.
Consider edge cases where no pairs can be formed. For example, if your input is ['ab', 'cd'], you will not be able to create any palindrome.
As you build your palindrome, keep track of the total length. Each pair contributes 4 to the length, and a single palindromic word contributes 2 if used in the center.
Think about how to iterate through your dictionary of words and their counts. You might want to use a loop to check each word and its reverse.
After calculating the total length from pairs, check if you can add a center word. If you have any palindromic words left, you can add one to increase the length by 2.
Finally, ensure your return value is the total length you calculated. Remember to handle cases where no palindrome can be formed by returning 0.

questionNotes: words[i] consists of lowercase English letters.
Each element can be selected at most once.
